>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
>
>It sounds like under that scheme the worst individuals have the same
>chance of reproducing as the best?

If you had a population where 90% were all within 10% of the fitness range, 
and the other 10% were scattered around the remaining range, and you chose 
who to reproduce by random selection (roulette wheel, yes?), then the result 
would be that 90% of those who were reproducing will also be in that range, 
leaving very little represenation of what lies outside of it.

Whereas, by randomly selecting a fitness value and then selecting the member 
of the population closest to that, then in that case you would end up with 
(ideally) a fairly complete representation of the whole spectrum.  It means 
that oddballs are more likely to pass on their genes, just because they are 
different than the rest.  The 90% of the population, since they only 
represent 10% of the total range of fitness values, only get a 10% 
representation in the selection process.  So whether or not any particular 
network has the same chances of reproducing as another network really 
depends on how close to the center of a cluster it might be.

>That does sound like it preserves diversity but it has almost no 
>convergence.

As described, true.

Assume that all networks chosen for breeding are passed on as elites, plus 
one or two asexual reproductions each and the rest through crossover.  This 
would definitely encourage diversity, which can either speed up or 
significantly slow down the search, depending on how you look at it.  But it 
would virtually eliminate convergence.

Now, if you first select the champion network for breeding before selecting 
any others, then it should converge just fine, while still preserving 
diversity, and *maybe* increasing the search's ability to escape a local 
optima.

>Perhaps if you want diversity a roulette wheel method would be better.

How would that work, exactly?
